Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.raw_text: Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.proposition: A persistent infestation that materially interferes with habitability and ordinary use of the premises may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and related landlord obligations.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 624 A.2d 1002 (Vt..proposition: Hilder v. St. Peter, 624 A.2d 1002 (Vt. 1993) (and other cases discussing warranty of habitability and landlord's duty to remedy significant defects and infestations) — cited for persuasive authority on habitability and remedial obligations

Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.raw_text: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316, 391 N.E.2d 1288 (N.Y. 1979)
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.proposition: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316, 391 N.E.2d 1288 (N.Y. 1979) (on landlord duties and tenant remedies) — persuasive authority
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.case_name: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses both landlord duties and tenant remedies in residential leases. It adopts and explicates the implied warranty of habitability, describes the landlord’s nondelegable duty to maintain premises fit for human habitation (including during work stoppages), and explains available tenant remedies such as rent abatement and damages. As a leading New York Court of Appeals decision on these issues, it is strong persuasive authority on landlord duties and tenant remedies even outside New York.
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.relevant_excerpt: “A residential lease is now effectively deemed a sale of shelter and services by the landlord who impliedly warrants: first, that the premises are fit for human habitation… Inasmuch as the landlord is vested with the ultimate control and responsibility for the building, it is he who has a corresponding nondelegable and nonwaivable duty to maintain it. The obligation of the tenant to pay rent is dependent upon the landlord’s satisfactory maintenance of the premises in habitable condition… the proper measure of damages for breach of the warranty is the difference between the fair market value of the premises if they had been as warranted… and the value of the premises during the period of the breach.”

Green v. Superior Court.proposition: Green v. Superior Court (commonly cited in landlord-tenant habitability jurisprudence in various jurisdictions) — persuasive authority on tenant protections

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Consumer Protection Act) — cited for context regarding unfair or deceptive conduct by landlords (no separate statutory claim pleaded)

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 (Public health statutes) and related local health codes regarding vermin, sanitation, and nuisance abatement (public health enforcement context)
